Since justices serve for life, do you think that appointing a 71 year old justice to the Supreme Court makes sense, in the long run? Also, her experience has been family court, not matters of constitutional law, so she would be out of her depth.

Marilyn, while I agree that her age would be an issue, I disagree that she'd be out of her depth.  Any half-decent lawyer is qualified to opine on Constitutional law -- it's part of our foundational training.

Let's get some sense within the Supreme Court - that's where she is needed!  One more brilliant female who knows what's going on, what needs to be protected, and a superb knowledge of how our Constitution needs sane rulings in protecting rights for all.
Patrick, you must not understand that plaintiffs and defendants CHOOSE justice by Judge Judy, as preferable to "jury of peers."

Very few small claims cases go before a jury. In filing in Small Claims Court one agrees to accept the ruling of the judge though appeal is possible. You have a limited amount of time to file one. I've been to Small Claims many times, enough to respect these judges who seem able to spot liars and habitual cheats in an instant.

Judge Judy is a national show. Small claims procedures vary by jurisdiction.  In some states, such as Connecticut you CANNOT appeal the ruling.  What's worse the chances are you are not heard by or the case ruled upon by a judge, but my a lawyer acting as a part-time magistrate.
The shows are an afront to the American concept of justice by a jury of peers. I'm not surprised President Obama likes her. By the way, the network does call itself CBS.

I'm reminded of one of our finest novelists - and a winner of one of the major book awards - who keeps a very low profile. Lives reasonably well in a remote location in the upper northwest, every few years teaches for a semester at a state college in the area they were raised in, for financial stability and because they like teaching. They really only surface when a book is published and then give only a few public readings and rarely submit to interviews. 30 years into their career, they appear to have reasonable financial success and have done superb work. They are on no level a celebrity but I think their work is universally respected by other writers.

It's true some writers become very wealthy and become celebrities or move in a status-conscious social pecking order. My experience has been that those are people who always wanted those things in their life regardless of what they chose to do. Being a writer is incidental to having such needs/desires.

It's odd to me the extent to which the two talented writers interviewed here are conflating writing with the desire for these external things - money, fame, attention, validation, an audience, a particular social status.

Everything in this country now revolves around wealth and celebrity status.

No, Kairos, inadvertent or otherwise I do not agree with Jesse Eisenger's point of view. But I do appreciate his presentation of debatable points without the rancor that often accompanies any discussion of Secretary Geithner's actions and motivations.

I am, in fact, very glad that Tim did not have the kind of vision that many on the left suggest that he should have had. History alone will, of course, be the final arbitrator.

For more than seven years I was a critic of practically everything that President George W. Bush did. However, I felt then and still believe that he handled the financial crisis in a brave, intelligent and honorable manner. He listened to Ben Bernanke, Hank Paulson and (although I didn't know it at the time) Tim Geithner to create TARP against the strong opposition of many in his party. I give him full credit and to President Obama for his subsequent reasonable actions. Perhaps different, "bolder" strategies would have still averted a second Great Depression and accomplished much more as Eisinger and others passionately suggest. I am just grateful that our economy is as strong as it is and that we did not descend into a financial abyss.

And finally as a math teacher of nearly 50 years I must protest your use of the 1%-99% dichotomy. It would be less disingenuous to assert that the top 80% were clearly helped by two Administrations' actions but that we still struggle to assist the other 20% many of whom I see in my community college classes.

The question is whether the differences between the two parties are more important than the similarities. During the financial crisis the two parties both supported bailing out the banks (albeit while complaining loudly to the contrary. And they both opposed bailing out home owners (albeit while waxing eloquently about the problems they were facing.) And they spent almost two years agreeing that someone making $50,000 should continue to get a tax break of $600 while arguing about whether someone making $500,000 should get a tax break of $8000 or $17000. So which is more important, that they agreed on a huge tax break for the wealthy (larger than the middle class even proportional to their income) or that they disagreed about how much bigger it should be?

There are differences and we are forced to choose between them. But we are making choices between A an B when there is full alphabet of alternatives out there.

Really? With all the errors cited, Piketty is becoming the Lyndon LaRouche of economists.

Someone wants to wear a tin-foil hat, that's on them, and no one else. Leave the working class alone, we're paying for 47,000,000 on food stamps.

Actually, Piketty's research is on the upper class, not the rest of us. The gap is not between the working class and the extremely poor, nor between the middle class and the working class; the growing gap is between the middle class and the upper class, and he is focusing on what it will mean when the children of rich entrepreneurs who actually founded a business that created jobs, inherit and simply collect rents or focus on the return on investments as shareholders and do not contribute one iota to society. The old captains of industry are dying and in their place are successors who have growing political power without working for it.
Also, the concept of "little people," which may have prompted your post, is a translation of "popolo minuto," a lower strata of fourteenth century Florence who revolted, successfully, and put fear in the hearts of the wealthy Florentine merchant class.
That will be interesting---reading it quickly.

Oh no! It's on my summer reading. I'd better read it quickly before more people pick holes in it!

Actually, Piketty's tone is refreshing in that he has put the information out where we can all see it. Whether or not there are discrepancies, whether some people are a lot richer than the rest of us, or just somewhat richer, it is not good for societies which have such a divide, historically. We need a serious discussion, too, not just gawking like that old TV show that came on late at night with announcer with a British accent, "Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous." We would snicker and our kids would make fun of the whole show--it was so strange. But really, if some people, especially decision-makers, are living in a world so different than what the rest of us inhabit, how can they make good decisions? How can they have any idea? Do they even care about the "little people?" History will tell, if this rentier class does expand more and more. Only 74 years passed between the death of Louis XIV and 1789, and I think Piketty is simply giving us a heads' up.

Of course the FT would love to show that such an unacceptable conclusion as the rich--their clientele--getting richer is not true. And that the rest of us are not being taken advantage of by the plutocrats who appear to be able to buy their way out of all their crimes.

MCE,

David Underwood was talking about Credit Suisse, which allowed US Citizens to create hidden bank accounts, something allowed by Swiss law. They didn't do anything that caused "the loss of millions of jobs" as you say.
Surely, if the FBI can put mug shots of Chinese hackers on wanted posters for doing what is legal, and indeed state-sponsored, in their country, they can do it with Swiss bankers, too.

I was speaking more generally about large US banks. I am also amazed at the lack of action directed towards Moody's and S&P who rated risky financial instruments as AAA and facilitated the very aggressive mortgage markets that collapsed quite quickly.

How do you jail a corporation, or a bank?
The charter can be revoked, putting the bank out of business.
Is that what you want Joe? Besides, the upper management is in Switzerland, and I doubt they could be jailed. It is an appeal to prejudice to make the statement, "Too Big To Jail," but it is in fact impractical. Do you really think the bank president would be jailed, or how about the board of directors, do you propose to jail them?

Probably the most culpable is the account manager, but he was working within Swiss law. Then there is the problem of runs. If Credit Suisse can be put out and BNP is next, there will be a run on them, and the FDIC will have to cover any U.S. depositor losses. But the runs will not stop there, any bank that is even suspect will be the next in line for a run.

It sounds good to call for a death penalty, but all you do is put the customers out of business. Investment and commercial accounts are not covered by the FDIC, so any hint that the bank will be put out of business, and the run is on.
